prompt:
Nurse: I'm glad to hear that, Mr. O'Leary. How has your day been so far?

Patient: You know, it's It's going alright. Nothing too exciting, but nothing to complain about. How about you? How are you feeling?

Nurse: I'm here to assist you, Mr. O'Leary, and I'm glad to hear your day is going well. It's not about me, but I appreciate your thoughtfulness. I'm sure you must be looking forward to getting a new knee. Do you have any plans for what you'd like to do once you've recovered from your surgery?

Patient: I might start taking Zoom book classes. That seems fun to me.

Nurse: That sounds like a wonderful plan, Mr. O'Leary. Zoom book classes can be a great way to stay engaged and learn new things. How are you feeling about your upcoming procedure?

Patient: I don't know. I'm not I'm not thrilled about it, to be honest.

Nurse: I can imagine that it's a bit daunting, Mr. O'Leary. It's completely normal to have some apprehension before a procedure. Do you have any specific questions or concerns you'd like to discuss before we move forward?

Patient: I mean, is this really gonna make any difference in my pain level?

responses.gpt4: Yes, Mr. O'Leary, a total knee replacement is considered one of the safest and delivers reliable outcomes for reducing pain caused by osteoarthritis. About 90-95% of knee replacements are still functioning well after 10 to 15 years. With your new knee and taking the proper time to heal, it is expected that your pain level will considerably decrease. Shall we move on to ensure you have everything ready for the procedure?
responses.our_model: That's a very valid concern, Mr. O'Leary. Total knee replacement is one of the most successful procedures in all of medicine. It's designed to relieve pain and help you get back to doing the things you enjoy. Doctor Cristina Stevens, your surgeon, is highly experienced and has performed over 1000 total knee replacements. She's known for her excellent outcomes. Do you have any other questions or concerns you'd like to discuss?
